head.title: Into America: How Open a Door?

hedline.hl1: Into America: How Open a Door?

abstract.p: Ann Keely letter responds to July 24 news article on increase in foreign-born population in New York; suggests influx of immigrants does not offset population losses but rather prompts long-term residents to leave (S)

block.p: According to ''40 Percent in New York Born Abroad'' (news article, July 24), immigration is offsetting population lost to death and relocation. Without it, says Dr. Philip Kasinitz, a sociology professor quoted in the article, the city would see ''neighborhood abandonment and depopulation.''

According to ''40 Percent in New York Born Abroad'' (news article, July 24), immigration is offsetting population lost to death and relocation. Without it, says Dr. Philip Kasinitz, a sociology professor quoted in the article, the city would see ''neighborhood abandonment and depopulation.''

But perhaps it is the other way around: as new population flows into the city, bringing crowded schools, congested streets and housing shortages, long-term residents leave, seeking more habitable space elsewhere. It's hard to know here whether the chicken came first, or the egg.
